titleStmt.title: A message sent from the city of London, to the King Majesty in the Isle of Wight, declaring their resolution touching the speedy bringing of His Majesty to His royall palace at White-Hall, and the manner thereof. Subscribed by the royall-hearted citizens. Also, the declaration of the Queen of England, concerning Her royall consort King Charles; and Her letter to the Prince of Wales, touching the Earl of Warwick. Agreed upon by the Queens Maiesty, and Her councell at St. Jermins, and published throughout the Kingdome of France.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 10 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

notesStmt.note: Transcribed from: (Early English Books Online ; image set 162374)

titleStmt.title: A message sent from the city of London, to the King Majesty in the Isle of Wight, declaring their resolution touching the speedy bringing of His Majesty to His royall palace at White-Hall, and the manner thereof. Subscribed by the royall-hearted citizens. Also, the declaration of the Queen of England, concerning Her royall consort King Charles; and Her letter to the Prince of Wales, touching the Earl of Warwick. Agreed upon by the Queens Maiesty, and Her councell at St. Jermins, and published throughout the Kingdome of France.
titleStmt.author: Vandieu, L.

notesStmt.note: Consists of a letter claiming the Queens support for the treaty with Parliament, dated and signed: Paris 26 Octob. 1648. L. Vandieu. And of news reports regarding negotiations for peace and the royal family.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Henrietta Maria, -- Queen, consort of Charles I, King of England, 1609-1669.
Great Britain -- History -- Civil War, 1642-1649 -- Peace -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: A MESSAGE SENT From the City of London, to the King Maje≈øty in the I≈øle of Wight, Declaring their Re≈øolutions touching the ≈øpeedy bringing of His Maje≈øty to His Royall Palace at White-Hall, and the manner thereof.
ALSO, The Declaration of the Queen of England, concerning Her Royall Con≈øort King Charles; and Her Letter to the Prince of Wales, touching the Earl of WARWICK.
AGreed upon by the Queens Maie≈øty, and Her Councell a ‚Ä¢ St. Jermins, and publi≈øhed throughout the Kingdome of France.

figure.head: M R
figure.figDesc: depiction of Queen Henrietta Maria, wife of King Charles I of England

figure.head: C R
figure.figDesc: depiction of King Charles I of England

div.head: THE QUEEN OF ENGLANDS Declaration at Paris in France.
Concerning Her Royall Con≈øort the King of Great Brittain; Declaring her Re≈øolution touching the Treaty at Newport, and the Parliament at We≈øtmin≈øter.
div.p:
VVHereas (with much patience) I have long bedeld the mi≈øeries of your di≈øtracted Kingdom, and finding
nothing more in≈øtrumentall for the ≈øetling of a firme and la≈øting peace, then the ble≈ø≈øed Treaty now on foot, I therefore thought requi≈øite, to ca≈øt my thoughts thereon, and to make it the chiefe≈øt Object of my affections, by indeavouring the propagating thereof in the≈øe parts, and cleering all ≈øcruples that may ari≈øe from the adver≈øe party, which I find to be many. But ker Maje≈øty the Queen of Great Brittain, hath declared the ≈øen≈øe of her Royall Brea≈øt, touching the pre≈øent Work in di≈øpute between the King and Parliament, and is plea≈øed to ca≈øt a favourable con≈øtruction thereon; and by rea≈øon of the many a≈øper≈øons laid upon her Maje≈øty, repre≈øenting her as an Enemy to the peace of England, after con≈øultation with her Councel at St. Jermins, ≈øhe re≈øolved to declare her intentions & determinations to the view of the World, and gave expre≈ø≈øe command to her Secretary to draw up a Declaration to be forthwith printed, the heads whereof are the≈øe.
1 That Her Majesty de≈øires nothing more then a compo≈øure of all differences betweene, Her dread Soveraigne Lord the King, and his two Hou≈øes of the Parliament of England a≈øsembled at We≈øtminster.
2 That Her Maje≈øty ≈øhall indeavour the propagating of this pre≈øent Treaty, and de≈øire a ≈øpeedy agreement, between Her Soveraign and His two Hou≈øes, that ≈øo peace may be e≈øtabli≈øhed throughout His Realmes and Dominions.
3 That Her Majesty ≈øhall indeavour the removing of all Ob≈øtacles that may retard or hinder this pre≈øent work in hand; provided, that She may enjoy the liberty of Her Con≈øcience for Her Self and Her Family, according to the Articles of both Kingdoms.
That Her Maje≈øty may be admitted to come for England ≈øo ≈øoon as the Articles of Agreement are ≈øigned and that She may be admitted to Her Royall Con≈øort, in honor, freedom, and ≈øafety.
The≈øe and many other particulars are contained in the ≈øaid Declaration, which is now extant among≈øt us, and are very ≈øatisfactory.

We hear that Her Maje≈øty hath ≈øent a Letter to the Prince of Wales, dehorting him from an Engagement with the Earl of Warwick, and to endeavour the ≈øetling of a peace between the King and Parliament, and it is hoped he will much incline to the ≈øaid advice and councell.

But here is a rumour, that his Highne≈ø≈øe hath ≈øent Propo≈øitions to the States of Holland, purporting His De≈øires, for the Dutch Fleer to continue betweene the two Navies, to hinder an Engagement, that ≈øo the ≈øtately Fabrick of his Fathers Shipping may be pre≈øerved and the mutuall League and Covenant between the States and the Crowne of England firmly kept and maintained.
In a word, Great are our expectations for the Tydings of peace, who≈øe hearts thir≈øt after unity and concord, which I de≈øire may be communicated to him who remaineth,

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt obliged and devoted friend, L. VANDIEU.

div.head: The la≈øt Newes from the Treaty.
div.p: THE Commi≈ø≈øioners proceed according to their In≈øtructions, de≈øiring His Maj. to give His Royal A≈ø≈øent for the confirming of the Presbyterian Government, and the aboli≈øhing of Bi≈øhops and Epi≈øcopacy for the future.

This motion cau≈øeth ≈øome ≈øcruple to ari≈øe from His Majesty, but after mature deliberation thereupon, returneth a ≈øatisfactory An≈øwer to the Commi≈ø≈øioners, in≈øomuch that it is conceived, He will give His Royall Word for pa≈ø≈øing the ≈øaid Bill, according to the time and manner prefixed by both Hou≈øes of Parliament; which cau≈øeth a di≈ømall frown to proceed from the adver≈øe party.

And His Majestic being ≈øen≈øible of their pre≈øent di≈øcontents and murmurings, gave expre≈ø≈øe Command, that proclamation ≈øhould be made throughout the ≈øaid I≈øland, for the preventing of all In≈øurrections and commotions during the time of the Treaty, which was accordingly done.

So that there is great hopes that all Ob≈øtacles will be removed, which may prove prejudiciall to this Treaty, or fru≈øtrate the endeavours and con≈øultation of the great Councell a≈ø≈øembled, who are even upon the clo≈øe of a finall end and Agreement.

His Maie≈øty ≈øaith, that He hath ≈øome few things to propound to the Commi≈ø≈øioners, which will give great ≈øatisfaction to His two Hou≈øes, and remove all jealou≈øies and fears what≈øoever from among≈øt His liege people of England; the ≈øaid Propo≈øals are to be debated at the Councell Table, ≈øo ≈øoon as his Maie≈øty hath received
the ≈øen≈øe of His two Hou≈øes, to his la≈øt Conce≈ø≈øions for aboli≈øhing of Epi≈øcopacy.

His Maje≈øties Coun≈øell hath declared a great liking of this their Soveraigns Re≈øolution, and in particular, the Bi≈øhop of London, who this morning told the King. That he had ≈øeriou≈øly meditated upon the Originall Grounds of Presbytery, and found them con≈øonant to the Word of God, and agreeable to the ≈øacred Rules Ordained by the Apo≈øtles and Evangeli≈øts in the holy Scriptures, and therefore conceived, that his Maje≈øty might in honour and con≈øcience give his Royall A≈ø≈øent for the more fully and firm ≈øetling of the Directory, &c.

The≈øe conde≈øcen≈øions from the pillars of Epi≈øcopacy, doth betoken a happy uniting and concurrence to Presbytery; which being once a≈ø≈øented to, there's no doubt but all other Ob≈øtacles will ≈øoon be removed, and the ≈øilver cords of Amity firmly knit, and unite the hearts both of Prince and people, in peace and tranquility.

We hear that there hath been a late De≈øign complotting by the Enemies of Religion, again≈øt the King and Kingdom, who had con≈øpired to rai≈øe a great army throughout the Kingdom of England, by tendering an Oath of Secre≈øie, a Party whereof to gather to a head in the We≈øt, and ≈øeverall other parts of the Kingdome for the re≈øcuing his Maie≈øty from the power of the Parliament, and to bring him to London by force, if they do not condi≈øcend to his De≈øires, and to put mo≈øt of them to the ≈øword. But by the divine providence of the All-≈øeeing Iehovah, their Plot is di≈øcovered, and by his omnipotency quite fru≈øtrated and prevented.

postscript.p: Letters from the We≈øt ≈øay, That it is conceived his Maje≈øty will go neer to ≈øign to all the propo≈øitions upon Friday next, notwith≈øtanding what hath verbally pa≈øt to the contrary. The Lord Duke of Richmond, and the Marquis of Hartford, admire his Maje≈øties wi≈ødome in carrying on this Treaty, and have protested that they do not know by what Coun≈øell the King governs his actions.

Divers Agents are ≈øaid to be ≈øent from the Queen and the Prince to the King, with Letters of great importance. As al≈øo a me≈ø≈øage from the City of London ≈øub≈øcribed by the Royall party, intimating, Their private de≈øign in li≈øting of new forces, for the advancement of his Maje≈øties Cau≈øe, and re-inve≈øting Him in his Royall Throne; but by an unheard of ≈øtratageme their de≈øign is prevented, and their plot revealed.
